comments:
LGST210 explores business responsibility from rival theoretical and managerial perspectives. Its focus includes theories of ethics and their application to case studies in business. Topics include moral issues in advertising and sales; hiring and promotion; financial management; corporate pollution; product safety; and decision-making across borders and cultures. 

Student feedback for this course was mixed. Some found the course to be “too open ended” with too much emphasis on class discussion while others very much enjoyed the “quite interesting” and “insightful” discussions. 

Professor Radin also received mixed reviews. One student felt that “Radin has an excellent ability to engage students and offer interesting frameworks for thinking” but some believed her to be “preachy” and “abrasive at times.” Students disagreed on Radin’s dedication to the class. Some felt that she “truly cared and got to know her students” and was a “very involved instructor” while others complained that she was a “slow grader who did not provide adequate feedback.”

Course requirements include class participation and two written assignments. Given the emphasis on class discussion, some students recommended that students who do not enjoy speaking in class should not take this class. Many students were frustrated by the lack of feedback given through the semester, but a majority of the students still enjoyed the course.

LGST210 explores business responsibility from rival theoretical and managerial perspectives. Its focus includes theories of ethics and their application to case studies in business. Topics include moral issues in advertising and sales; hiring and promotion; financial management; corporate pollution; product safety; and decision-making across borders and cultures. 

Many students reported learning a great deal about philosophy as it applied to corporate ethics. Students agreed that there was “too much emphasis on philosophy” and “not enough business applications,” however, many still enjoyed the course and felt it to be worthwhile.

Overall, students thought that Professor Sepinwall was a good instructor who was “enthusiastic about the material”. One commented that “Professor Sepinwall is very knowledgeable, leads a good discussion, and refrains from stating her opinions on the somewhat controversial material. I have had other classes at Wharton where professors seem to favor students who agree with their opinions; this was not the case with her.” Some students felt that Professor Sepinwall moved “too quickly” in class.

Course requirements include an in-class midterm, a take-home final, and class participation. Most students agreed that the readings were “interesting” and did not complain about the assessments. A few students wished that there had been more weight placed on class participation to encourage more people to speak up in class.

Topics include moral issues in advertising and sales; hiring and promotion; financial management; corporate pollution; product safety; and decision-making across borders and cultures. 

Many students reported learning a great deal about philosophy as it applied to corporate ethics. Students agreed that there was “too much emphasis on philosophy” and “not enough business applications,” however, many still enjoyed the course and felt it to be worthwhile.

Overall, students thought that Professor Sepinwall was a good instructor who was “enthusiastic about the material”. One commented that “Professor Sepinwall is very knowledgeable, leads a good discussion, and refrains from stating her opinions on the somewhat controversial material. I have had other classes at Wharton where professors seem to favor students who agree with their opinions; this was not the case with her.” Some students felt that Professor Sepinwall moved “too quickly” in class.

Course requirements include an in-class midterm, a take-home final, and class participation. Most students agreed that the readings were “interesting” and did not complain about the assessments. A few students wished that there had been more weight placed on class participation to encourage more people to speak up in class.

LGST210 explores business responsibility from rival theoretical and managerial perspectives. Its focus includes theories of ethics and their application to case studies in business. Topics include moral issues in advertising and sales; hiring and promotion; financial management; corporate pollution; product safety; and decision-making across borders and cultures. 

Feedback for this course was positive on a whole. Some students stated that it was “the best class they have ever taken!” Students commented that “the atmosphere in his classroom is very friendly and humorous and discussion/questions are always welcome.” A few wished there had been “a little more structure.”

Students praised Professor Laufer, categorizing him as “absolutely brilliant,” with many stating that he was their “favorite professor at Penn.” Students agreed that Professor Laufer was “highly invested in the course.”

Course requirements include class participation, a debate, midterm, and a final. Some students felt that the readings were “overwhelming” but others said there was “little formal work required.”
